   <entry>
      <id>467260</id>
      <title>Moth thought extinct found by amateur lepidopterist</title>
      <updated>2018-02-17</updated>
      <author>
         <name>By Evelyn Ring, Irish Examiner Reporter</name>
      </author>
      <link rel="alternate" href="http://feeds.examiner.ie/~r/ietopstories/~3/Kj1wmTfti0s/moth-thought-extinct-found-by-amateur-lepidopterist-467260.html" />
      <summary type="html"><p>Moths might not look spectacular, but amateur lepidopterist, Philip Strickland, knew it was a rare find.</p></summary>
      <content type="html"><p><p>Moths might not look spectacular, but amateur lepidopterist, Philip Strickland, knew it was a rare find.</p></p><p>Called The Suspected <strong>&mdash; Parastichtis suspecta&nbsp;</strong><strong>&mdash;&nbsp;</strong>it was thought to be extinct in Ireland. It was last spotted in 1962.</p>
<p>Mr Strickland found eight of the brown moths in Lullymore Heritage and Discovery Park, in Rathangan Co Kildare, last July, indicating that they were very happy there.</p>
<p>The species inhabits woodland and heathland, and the larvae feed on birch and willow. They are on the wing in late July and August.</p>
<p>It is not known why the moth almost became extinct, but it is believed deforestation and peat-extraction destroyed their natural habitat.</p>
<p>The manager of Lullymore Heritage and Discovery Park, Ray Stapleton, said the park had been used by Bord na M&oacute;na for decades to extract peat and once resembled a black desert.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Since 2011, we have been trying to prove that these cutaways are not wastelands, but, potentially, very biodiverse habitats that will also attract tourism to an area that traditionally never had it,&rdquo; said Mr Stapleton.</p>
<p>&ldquo;The potential for numerous species to thrive in such a diverse habitat is great, as we have seen through Philip&rsquo;s work.&rdquo;</p>
<p>As well as moths, the park is now home to red squirrels, pine martens, hares, lapwings, buzzards, newts, frogs, and butterflies.</p>
<p>Mr Stapleton said a former <strong>Irish Examiner&nbsp;</strong>columnist, the late Dick Warner, spent many years helping the park to develop the peatland biodiversity area.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It may take a while to happen, but I firmly believe that this is a win-win situation, as our peatlands biodiversity area is really beneficial to the environment and is key to us attracting tourism from all over the world.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Mr Strickland said there were about five records of The Suspected from five different sites in Ireland, but the last time it was seen was 56 years ago.</p>
<p>He uses a moth trap that has an ultraviolet light and empty egg cartons. The moths are attracted to the light, make contact with the plastic veins, and drop down into the trap.</p>
<p>&ldquo;The moths sit happily in the egg cartons, until I release them unharmed, the next morning, into the vegetation nearby,&rdquo; he said.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I have been studying moths for more than 20 years, but I do have a desk job.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I would describe myself as an amateur lepidopterist.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The name &lsquo;lepidopterist&rsquo; is derived from the name of the order of butterflies and moths, Lepidoptera.</p>
<p>Mr Strickland is a member of Moths Ireland, a group of amateurs and professionals.</p>
<p>They collect and collate records for the National Biodiversity Data Centre in Carriganore, Co Waterford.</p>
<p>The data centre is funded by the Department of Arts, Heritage, Regional Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs and the Heritage Council.</p>
<p>Mr Strickland is planning to continue examining moth species in Lullymore Heritage and Discovery Park this year.</p>
<p>He recorded 201 species there last year.</p>
<p>&ldquo;The site is proving to be of national significance, with the recording of a considerable number of rare and scarce species,&rdquo; he said.</p>
<p>&ldquo;The site is really doing well, as it has a great mix of habitat. The Scots pine and birch woodland, with the undergrowth of bilberry, is a really important native habitat and is producing great records.&rdquo;</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ietopstories/~4/Kj1wmTfti0s" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content>

   <entry>
      <id>467259</id>
      <title>Man who tried to flee court is sent forward for trial</title>
      <updated>2018-02-17</updated>
      <author>
         <name />
      </author>
      <link rel="alternate" href="http://feeds.examiner.ie/~r/ietopstories/~3/vyvp_AQKuHQ/man-who-tried-to-flee-court-is-sent-forward-for-trial-467259.html" />
      <summary type="html"><p>A man has been sent forward for trial, on a plea of guilty, for trying to escape garda custody in a courthouse, and on a charge of assault, relating to the same incident.</p></summary>
      <content type="html"><p><p>A man has been sent forward for trial, on a plea of guilty, for trying to escape garda custody in a courthouse, and on a charge of assault, relating to the same incident.</p></p><p>James McCarney, 40, had previously appeared in the district court on February 7, in relation to charges of dangerous driving and of having no insurance at a garda checkpoint the previous day.</p>
<p>At that court appearance, he was refused bail and then appeared to try and flee the courtroom. He was tackled by a number of garda&iacute;, one of whom was injured.</p>
<p>That led to a subsequent court appearance, a week ago, in Bandon District Court. There, Mr McCarney, who has given an address at Balmore, Torrance, in Glasgow, and also at Rossmore, Clonakilty, in Co Cork, was charged with assault and resisting a garda in the execution of his duty, at Macroom District Court, on February 7, and with attempting to escape from garda custody, at the court on the same date.</p>
<p>Insp Pat Meany said, yesterday, that the Director of Public Prosecutions had directed the charges of dangerous driving and no insurance be dealt with at district court level, but that the two charges arising out of the incident at Macroom, on February 7, be sent forward to the Cork Circuit Criminal Court.</p>
<p>The previous court sitting involving Mr McCarney, a businessman, had heard that he had apologised for his actions and would be pleading guilty to the charges.</p>
<p>Bandon District Court heard, yesterday, that the DPP also consented to Mr McCarney being sent forward to the Cork Circuit Criminal Court on a signed plea &mdash; something which would speed up the trial process, as it would not require a book of evidence.</p>
<p>Mr McCarney&rsquo;s solicitor, Eamonn Fleming, said his client had already indicated a plea of guilty in relation to the dangerous-driving charge from the checkpoint at Tooreen, Ballinhassig, on February 6.</p>
<p>However, he said he was not in a position to advise as to the no-insurance charge faced by his client, as he had not seen an insurance policy, and documents had not been forthcoming.</p>
<p>He also applied, again, for his client to be released on bail, but Judge Mary Dorgan said she had already dealt with this. &ldquo;I am going to recuse myself from dealing with this matter,&rdquo; she said, and that the alleged incident on February 7 had happened in her court and that it was &ldquo;important for justice to be done and for justice to be seen to be done&rdquo;.</p>
<p>She said she had organised for another judge to hear the district court matters, next Thursday, but Mr Fleming said he could not say whether he would have received all the information he required, so as to enter a plea, by then. Those matters will be mentioned on March 2, while Mr McCarney will be sent forward for trial, possibly as early as next week, in the Circuit Criminal Court, regarding the February 7 incident.</p>
<p>Mr Fleming said this would happen on a signed plea of guilty and added: &ldquo;The matter can be dealt with more promptly in the circuit court.&rdquo;</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ietopstories/~4/vyvp_AQKuHQ" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content>

   <entry>
      <id>467253</id>
      <title>G-section: How a Cork-born doctor delivered a baby gorilla by caesarean</title>
      <updated>2018-02-17</updated>
      <author>
         <name>By Catherine Shanahan, Health Correspondent</name>
      </author>
      <link rel="alternate" href="http://feeds.examiner.ie/~r/ietopstories/~3/mcVC1kzfApg/g-section-how-a-cork-born-doctor-delivered-a-baby-gorilla-by-caesarean-467253.html" />
      <summary type="html"><p>Not many men can claim to have helped impregnate a gorilla or to have delivered a primate by caesarean section, but David Cahill&rsquo;s CV is fairly unique, even in the radical world of fertility medicine.</p></summary>
      <content type="html"><p><p>Not many men can claim to have helped impregnate a gorilla or to have delivered a primate by caesarean section, but David Cahill&rsquo;s CV is fairly unique, even in the radical world of fertility medicine.</p></p><p>So far, so bizarre, particularly as David&rsquo;s background is one of delivering human babies and treating human couples for fertility problems.</p>
<p>A consultant obstetrician/gynaecologist, originally from Donoughmore, Co Cork, David&rsquo;s involvement with the largest living primates goes back over a decade.</p>
<p>He studied medicine in University College Cork (UCC) and subsequently worked in the National Maternity Hospital in Dublin where he developed an interest in reproductive medicine, prompted by contact with Colm O&rsquo;Herlihy, now Professor of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at University College Dublin (UCD) School of Medicine and Medical Science.</p>
<p>David subsequently went to Bristol in the 1990s to study and &ldquo;never left&rdquo;. He is now Professor in Reproductive Medicine and Medical Education at Bristol University. His day job takes him to St Michael&rsquo;s University Hospital where his focus is on gynaecology, specifically fertility treatment.</p>
<p>His day job has also taken him to Bristol Zoo where he was centrally involved in an event which caught the public imagination: the delivery by C-section of a baby gorilla on account of concerns that its mother had pre-eclampsia. On February 10, that baby, named Afia, celebrated her second birthday.</p>
<p>So how does a doctor segue from babies to great apes?</p>
<p>&ldquo;Vets don&rsquo;t do IVF,&rdquo; he says.</p>
<p>David&rsquo;s involvement with Bristol Zoo goes back to 2004/2005 when the zoo&rsquo;s efforts to get a gorilla pregnant were unsuccessful. Thinking outside the box, the zoo made contact with David because of his background in reproductive medicine.</p>
<p>&ldquo;They knew I knew how to get people pregnant so they asked if I could help,&rdquo; he says.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It was a bit of a challenge.&rdquo; It was &ldquo;practically impossible&rdquo; to do blood tests to measure the gorilla&rsquo;s hormones, (try approaching a moody gorilla with a syringe) so they had to depend on urine samples. David still has deep sympathy for the zookeeper whose task it was to retrieve urine samples every day for three months.</p>
<p>&ldquo;The enclosure was well-designed so that everything flowed into a hole in the middle and he was able to retrieve urine from that point,&rdquo; David says. The samples were sent to a German laboratory for analysis. It emerged the gorilla, Salome, was not ovulating.</p>
<p>&ldquo;So we gave her tablets to get her to ovulate, mixed in with her food, and she got pregnant,&rdquo; David says. She gave birth to a son, Komale.</p>
<p><p><figure class='imgFCap'><img src="https://media.central.ie/media/images/s/SurgeryForGorillaInBristolZoo160218a_large.jpg"><figcaption class='imgFCap'>Afia enjoying her birthday celebrations, with surrogate mother Romina. It is expected Afia will remain with her until she is five.</figcaption></figure></p><p></p>
<p>Having proved his usefulness, David was recalled two years ago when Kera the gorilla showed signs of pre-eclampsia while carrying Komale&rsquo;s child. David estimates she was &ldquo;38-39 weeks pregnant, but I can&rsquo;t be certain, apes don&rsquo;t have a last period and you can&rsquo;t ask them&rdquo;. He says the zoo was concerned about Kera and they got in touch with him on a Tuesday.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We planned to go and scan the mother on the Friday. There was a chance we might end up delivering the baby. But when I scanned her, it looked like the baby was really in trouble,&rdquo; he says.</p>
<p>The vets subsequently gave David the go-ahead to deliver, and Kera was taken by stretcher to a van and then to the vets&rsquo; working area. She was shaved, David put iodine on her tummy and donned sterile drapes.</p>
<p>So how different was it to delivering a human child?</p>
<p>&ldquo;The whole thing was very strange and very weird. It was a very different environment and the smells were different. Kera vomited before the operation, a smelly green mess. And there were so many photographs being taken.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It felt like it went on forever but my junior colleague (another doctor from St Michael&rsquo;s) said it only took three-quarters of an hour.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Was there a fear Kera would wake up during the operation?</p>
<p>&ldquo;I was anxious. The zoo-keepers were holding her arms and feet and occasionally one would say &lsquo;she&rsquo;s twitching&rsquo;. She&rsquo;d clobber me if she woke up and saw the knife,&rdquo; he says, laughing.</p>
<p>The surgery was trickier than a human delivery because of the different shape of the pelvis and uterus, but he managed it with minimal damage. The upshot was the birth of baby Afia, Ugandan for &ldquo;born on a Friday&rdquo;, and membership of an exclusive club of consultant obstetricians/gynaecologists to perform c-sections on gorillas.</p>
<p>&ldquo;There are reports of 12-15 c-sections worldwide,&rdquo; he says.</p>
<p>He is thankful he didn&rsquo;t have to remove Kera&rsquo;s stitches: &ldquo;We thought about that &mdash; and put in subcuticular stitches &mdash; ones that are under the skin, and dissolve by themselves.&rdquo;</p>
<p>He did undertake follow-up visits, but Kera was in a &lsquo;bad place&rsquo; for nine months after the birth. In retrospect, David and the vets believe she may have been suffering from kidney disease, not pre-eclampsia. She was subsequently treated with steroids and recovered.</p>
<p>He did visit Afia once a week for a couple of weeks after the birth, and she was doing well. And he has since taken his two-year-old granddaughter to see Afia but hasn&rsquo;t yet told her of his role in her existence.</p>
<p><p><figure class='imgFCap'><img src="https://media.central.ie/media/images/s/SurgeryForGorillaInBristolZoo160218b_large.jpg"><figcaption class='imgFCap'>The baby western lowland gorilla Afia, who celebrated her second birthday last Monday.</figcaption></figure></p><p></p>
<p>Meanwhile, his brothers at home in Ireland, Paul, Declan and Kieran, and his Dad, Pat, are dining out on David&rsquo;s walk into the gorilla hall of fame.</p>
<p>As for David?</p>
<p>&ldquo;I really didn&rsquo;t realise at the time that it was going to be such a big fuss, I was just doing the thing that I do. But in hindsight, it&rsquo;s brought me into contact with a fairly small and fairly unique, global community of people dedicated to conservation of gorillas. It makes me feel part of that community. There are only 300 gorillas or so in captivity worldwide, so in that sense, what we did was a very big deal.&rdquo;</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ietopstories/~4/mcVC1kzfApg" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content>
